qas.question: What Greek word defines as "follower of Christ?"
Where does the Greek word Χριστιανός (Christianos) come from?
What is the French word for Christian that was derived from Greek?
From which word meaning anointed one does Christos originate?
While Christianos means anointed one, what does Christos mean?
While Christos means follower of Christ, what does Christianos mean?
From who are words equivalent in meaning to 'Latin" derived?
In which religion does christos mean "one who is anointed'?

context: The Greek word <a0_0>Χριστιανός (<b4_0>Christianos<b4_0/>)<a0_0/>, meaning "<b5_0>follower of Christ<b5_0/>", comes from <a1_0>Χριστός (Christos)<a1_0/>, meaning "<a2_0><b6_0>anointed one<b6_0/><a2_0/>", with an adjectival ending borrowed from Latin to denote adhering to, or even belonging to, as in slave ownership. In the Greek Septuagint, christos was used to translate the <b8_0>Hebrew<b8_0/> מָשִׁיחַ (Mašíaḥ, messiah), meaning "[one who is] anointed." In other European languages, equivalent words to Christian are likewise derived from <b7_0>the Greek<b7_0/>, such as <a3_0>Chrétien<a3_0/> in French and Cristiano in Spanish.
